subject: Re: Getting @Ignore reported?
msgSnippet: ... Rocco, Thanks for the hint. I tried it, but it didn t seem to change the ant output: $ ant unittest [snip] unittest: [junit] Running TTest [junit] Tests
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Pigneri, Rocco" <rpigneri@...> wrote:
>
> Dear Bob,
>
>
>
> You need to use both the @Test and the @Ignore annotations in order to
> get the behavior that you want. Without the @Test annotation, the test
> runner does not consider the function a test and ignores it.
>
Rocco,
Thanks for the hint. I tried it, but it didn't seem to change the ant
output:

$ ant unittest
[snip]
unittest:
[junit] Running TTest
[junit] Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Time elapsed: 0.103 sec

[Note: no indication of ignored tests, above, or in the generated HTML
report.]

$ java -ea -cp /usr/share/java/junit4.jar:classes:test-classes
org.junit.runner.JUnitCore TTest
JUnit version 4.3.1
.I.
Time: 0.022

OK (2 tests)

At least the "native" runner indicates "I", which I'm assuming means
"ignored". Is there any runner/formatter combination that makes this
information more explicit?
Regards,
Bob
